step1_initial_points.title: Lawyer Inefficiency Due to Repetitive Tasks
step1_initial_points.description: AGS's lawyers spend significant time on low-value, manual tasks like summarizing long documents, creating first drafts from templates, and building case chronologies. This reduces time available for high-value strategic legal work and analysis.

step1_initial_points.title: Inconsistent Work Quality Across a Large Team
step1_initial_points.description: With approximately 570 lawyers across multiple offices, ensuring consistent adherence to AGS style guides, document quality, and plain English rules is a significant operational challenge, potentially leading to rework and brand dilution.

step1_initial_points.title: Difficulty in Finding Internal Knowledge
step1_initial_points.description: Lawyers struggle to efficiently locate relevant precedents, legal opinions, and expertise within AGS's existing knowledge bases. Poor search relevance and findability hinder productivity and the leveraging of collective organizational knowledge.

step1_initial_points.title: Meeting Stringent Government Security Requirements
step1_initial_points.description: Adopting AI tools is constrained by the need to meet strict Commonwealth security standards, including PROTECTED-level IRAP certification, data sovereignty (storage in Australia), and Essential Eight compliance, limiting the available vendor options.

step1_initial_points.title: Seamless Integration with Existing Tech Stack
step1_initial_points.description: Any new AI solution must integrate with core systems like iManage Cloud, Elite 3E, and Microsoft Office. Failure to do so would create data silos, disrupt established workflows, and hinder user adoption across the organization.

step1_initial_points.title: Risk of Falling Behind on AI Innovation
step1_initial_points.description: AGS is concerned with not just current generative AI, but also emerging 'agentic AI' capable of autonomous, multi-step tasks. There is a strategic need to explore these advanced capabilities to maintain a competitive edge and future-proof their services.

step1_initial_points.title: AI Governance, Ethics, and Explainability Risks
step1_initial_points.description: As a government legal provider, AGS faces significant reputational and legal risk. AI solutions must be ethical, transparent, and produce explainable outcomes to ensure accountability and maintain the trust of their government clients.

step1_initial_points.title: Inefficient Resource and Capacity Management
step1_initial_points.description: AGS needs to better manage lawyer workloads and allocate staff based on capacity, expertise, and availability. Current processes for work allocation and managing rosters (e.g., for graduate programs) are likely manual and time-consuming.

step1_initial_points.title: Slow Business Development and Bid Responses
step1_initial_points.description: The process of generating capability statements for bids, summarizing tender requirements, and drafting client briefings is manually intensive. This can slow down response times and limit the capacity to pursue new business opportunities effectively.

step3_refined_points.title: Operational Inefficiency from Manual Tasks
step3_refined_points.description: Lawyers and business development teams are bogged down by repetitive, low-value work like summarizing documents, drafting bids, and creating case chronologies. This limits time for high-value strategic work and slows business growth.

step3_refined_points.title: Poor Internal Knowledge Discovery
step3_refined_points.description: Lawyers struggle to locate relevant precedents, legal opinions, and internal expertise. Inefficient search and poor findability hinder productivity and the ability to leverage collective organizational knowledge for client work.

step3_refined_points.title: Risk of Falling Behind on AI Innovation
step3_refined_points.description: There is a strategic need to explore emerging AI, including 'agentic AI,' to maintain a competitive edge. Failure to innovate risks falling behind competitors and not being able to meet future client expectations for efficiency and service.

step3_refined_points.title: Inconsistent Work Quality and Standards
step3_refined_points.description: Ensuring consistent adherence to style guides, quality benchmarks, and plain English rules is a challenge across a large legal team. This inconsistency risks brand dilution, client dissatisfaction, and costly rework.

step3_refined_points.title: AI Governance, Ethics, and Explainability Risk
step3_refined_points.description: As a government provider, AI adoption carries significant reputational risk. Solutions must be ethical, transparent, and produce explainable outcomes to ensure accountability and maintain the trust of government clients.
